div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Eqyptians and English
div.p: New books on Eqypt appearing with such startling frequency, that one can hardly find time or space to review many of them. We have quite lately referred at some length to two important books, but the one under noticed by Mustapha Pacha Kamel, will not require such an effort. One cannot help asking whether it is probable that so many books can last. As to some, there may be much difference of opinion, but not so, we venture to think, with this particular book, which suggests to us the simile of a frail bark, built of materials well-nigh rotten before they were not put together, and covered with so thin a coat of varnish that it could not hope to float long on the sea of adverse currents and contrary winds, on which it has been launched. The book begins with a preface written by a French Lady wh enjoys a considerable literary reputation, but she has been in Egypt as a tourist, and our readers know only too well what the lady tourist can write on Egypt. It has often been said that the most important part of a lady's letter is generally in the postscript, and we think that this preface is no exceptiom to teh rule, for it tells ust hat the author of the book was only twenty-one years old when he delivered his first political oration at Toulouse in 1895; for the book consists of the reproduction of about a dozen political speeches made by the author between that date and 1904, and all of them on the same subject-- the abuse of the English occupation of Egypt. We are thus informed that the author was only eight years old at the time of the "events" in 1882, so that his personal experience of a previous state of things in Egypt could only of the very slightest; had it been greater, he would have known that if he or any of his countrymen had then dared,in the times to which he looks back with so much regret, to air their political opinions, with the same freedom which he has used, he would promptly have found himself up the White Nile or in some Egyptian prison from which he would have brought away lively recollections of personal discomfort. From further infromation we gather that the author, soon after he had finished wth the milk bottle, was sent t Frnace to imbibe knowledge at a seat of learning which was in those days a hotted for the cultivation of anti-english notions, and when he returned there, at the age of 21, the value of his own personal experience in this country could hardley be set at a very high figure. He wad cerainly gifted with very considerable fluency of speech, but he seems to forget, or tobe but little grateful for the fact, that it was only the fortunate circumstance of an English occupation which permitted him to make use of what in most Oriental countries is considered a very obnoxious qualification.

Our readers will appreciate the author's meagre personal experience; this might have been backed up by historical research as to the circumstances of otehr foreign occupations of this and other countries. Before he oublishes a second edtion we would recommend the author to read Napoleon's correspondence on the French occupation of Egypt, and the history of the first twenty years of their occupation of Augiere. From the first he would find that after a slight disturbance in Cairo, which had been out down with an iron hand, Napoleon writes to his General there to contine to cut off a few heads every day for some time, so as to maintain a proper amount of respect; from the second he would read of deeds of cruelty which might well make him shudder. Let him compare these with the state of Egypt during the last 24 years -- but fortunately the British occupation of Egypt does not want such an apologist as the author might have been, if better informed. Thst he should have published such a book 8 or 10 years ago would not have astonished us, but now that the "entente cordiale" has fortunately torn away the veil, through which our friends the French saw Egypt only dimly for so mant years, surely it is too late for the autor to expect that his visionary speeches can be of much interest. The "entente cordiale" must have indeed been a bitter pill to the atuhor; and when in addition to this he sees the rapid strides of improvement and progress in this country during the last few years, which even the casual observeer can recognize as only the first fruits of the harvest, the author must now realize that he in entirely out of tune with his surroundings. We understand that it is from Turkey that he derives his dignity of Pacha; in that less favoured country he would find a more fitting field for his genius, for which this country can no longer afford sufficient scope; he could well be spared here for he is only one of the drones who interfere with the working of the hive. We think the author would have been better advised not have been better advised not to have publised his book at all, but if he wished it to be widely read he certainly made a great mistake in putting the price so high as frs. 3.50.

div.head: Our Special Cables. South African Affairs. Mr. Balfour's Record Majority (Gazette Special Service.)
div.p: Lord Roberts, in the House of Lords, vigorously supported Lord Milner's attitude in regard to the granting of self government to the South African Colonies.
The "Time" correspondent at Pretoria telegraphs that Lord Milner's stalwart championship of the British cause evokes spontaneous gratitude on the part of the new population in South Afeica.
The new Lord Chancellor made a powerful reply to Lord Milner supporting the policy of the Government.
Mr. Balfour's majority of 11340 constitutes a record for this election.

div.head: Optimism At Algerciras (Gazette's Special Service)
div.p: There is a renewed feeling of optimism at Algerciras as to the outcome of the Conference.

div.head: AMERICAN STOCK AND SHARES(Gazette's Special Services.)
Local and General
div.p: Cattle Plague. Cattle plague has spread to the Tala and Kafr Cheikh districts
The Brindisi Mail. The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 4:30 p.m. today.
P.W.D. AWARD. The committee of the St. Louis World's Pair has recently sent to the Ministry of Public Works the diploma awarded to it for its Irrigation exhibit.
P.O. Savings Bank. The total number of depositors in the Post Office Savings Bank on the 3 at January last was 45, 054, and the sums deposited at that date totalled L.E.$50,219.
St. Patrick's Ball. The members of the sergeants mess of the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers will hold their annual St. Patrick's Ball in the mess-room. Mustapha Pacha on Tuesday, March 20th.

A Celebrated Violinist. The celebrated violinist Paul Kockanski will give a concert at the New Khedivial Hotel on Saturday next, March 3. The event should attract the whole of the musical world of Alexandria.

Coal Imports. The imports of coal from January 1 to the 22nd inst. amounted to 150,873 as against 86,918 tons came from Wales, 37,615 from Newsatle, 8,701 from the Scotch districts, and 19,077 from Yorkshire.

Savoy Ball. The management of the Savoy Hotel has fixed the date of the fancy dress ball for Tuesday next, March 6. Everybody remembers that last year's Savoy fancy-dress ball was one the best functions of the season, and this year's will no doubt be equally succesful.

New Employment Registry. The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it had commented an employment register, which may be consulted by members requring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be recieved, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain cost in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce. Alexandria.{Advt.]

La Valetta. The masked ball given yesterday evening, on the occasion of Shrove Tuesday, by the Valetta Maltese National Band at its rooms, was a great success. The ballroom was prettily decorate and illuminated with electricity, Maitre Mario Vella, president of the "Bands," as well as several other members of committee, accompanied by their wives, attended this fete, whcih lasted to an early hour this morning.
